thread.title: Owen Wright makes winning start in comeback from head injury
thread.title_full: Owen Wright makes winning start in comeback from head injury

author: Winsome Denyer
title: Owen Wright makes winning start in comeback from head injury
text:
Map: Newcastle 2300 
Former world number three surfer Owen Wright has made a triumphant return to competition in Newcastle, 15 months on from a serious head injury. 
The 27-year-old Australian was dominant in his heat against American Nathan Yeomans, and Brazilians Luel Felipe and Alan Donato at the Pro Qualifying Series round two event at Merewether Beach. External Link: OWright posts on Instagram 
He will now progress to the next round, as competition continues throughout the week. 
Wright suffered a traumatic brain injury and minor brain bleed after being pummelled by waves during a practice session before the Pipeline Masters event in Hawaii, in December 2015. 
"I've had the hardest year of my life and the biggest roller coaster," Wright said in his post-heat interview at Newcastle after Tuesday's competition. 
"I just feel on the other side of it now, and I feel better and stronger and I'm excited at the moment to have this rash shirt on again and compete." 
Wright was overcome with emotion when he returned to shore after taking out his heat with 7.90 and 7.43 his two top scores. 
His partner, musician Kita Alexander, and their baby son Vali, who was born in December, were there to watch his return to competition. 
"I'd like to thank all my friends and family and all the support from around the world that I've had since I had the injury," Wright said. 
"To realise how much love there is out there in this sport, and how much was sent my way that pushed me through that time, was just incredible. 
"Really soaking this moment in, I've worked really hard to get here." 
Wright's younger sister Tyler Wright, who is the reigning women's world champion, was her brother's primary carer for several weeks after his accident in Hawaii and has continued to support him throughout his recovery. 
Tyler Wright told the ABC's Australian Story program that recovery from a brain injury was a day-by-day process. 
"You read about people with similar cases to Owen, and their stories are all incredible because how hard they have had to fight to remain who they are, and I've watched it first-hand, the fight they have to get back to who they are," she said. 
Tyler Wright will feature in an upcoming episode of Australian Story, before she returns to competition in the 2017 Gold Coast Roxy Pro in March.
